captions.text: (music-dark/mysterious/percussive)
Adam Steltzner 'When people look at it...  uhhh, it looks crazy. That's a very natural thing.'
'Sometimes when we look at it, it looks crazy.'
'It is the result of reasoned, engineering thought.'
'But it still looks crazy.'
'From the top of the atmosphere, down to the surface-'
'It takes us seven minutes.'
'It takes 14 minutes or so for the signal from the spacecraft to make it to Earth-'
' that's how far Mars is away from us.'
'So, when we first get word that we've touched the top of the atmosphere,'

'the vehicle has been alive...'
(music intensifies- heavier percussion)

'or dead, on the surface, for at least seven minutes.'
(music crescendos- dark pounding drums)
Tom Rivellini: 'Entry, descent and landing, also known as EDL, is referred to as the '7 minutes of terror'.'
'Because we've got literally seven minutes to get from the top of the atmosphere to the surface of Mars-'
'going from 13,000 miles an hour to zero, in perfect sequence, perfect choreography, perfect timing...'
'and the computer has to do it all by itself, with no help from the ground.'
'If any one thing doesn't work just right, it's game over.'

(whoosh)
(music -tension/drums steadily building)
Adam Steltzner: 'We slam into the atmosphere and develop so much aerodynamic drag,'
'our heat shield, it heats up and it glows like the surface of the sun.'
Miguel San Martin: 'During entry, the vehicle is not only slowing down- violently, though the atmosphere,'
'but also we are guiding it, like an airplane! to be able to land in a very narrow, constrained space.'
'This is one of the biggest challenges that we are facing, and one that we have never attempted at Mars.'
Tom Rivellini: 'Mars- it's actually really hard to slow down,'
'because it has just enough atmosphere, that you have to deal with it-'
'otherwise, it will destroy your spacecraft.'
'On the other hand, it doesnt have enough atmosphere to finish the job.'
'We're still going about 1000 miles an hour.'
'So at that point we use a parachute.'
Anita Sengupta: 'The parachute is the largest and strongest super-sonic parachute-'
'that we've ever built to date.'
'It has to withstand 65,000 pounds of force! even though the parachute itself only weighs about 100 pounds.'
(blast-whoosh)
Tom Rivellini: 'When it opens up that fast, it's a neck-snapping 9G's!'
Steve Lee: 'At that point we have to get that heat shield off.'
'It's like a big lens cap, blocking our view of the ground to the radar.'
'The radar has to take just the right altitude and velocity measurements at just the right time-'
'or the rest of the landing sequence wont work.'

(heavy wind sound)
(music pulsing/intense)
Tom Rivellini: 'This big huge parachute that we've got-'
'it'll only slow us down to about 200 miles an hour.'
'And that's not slow enough to land.'
'So we have no choice but we've got to cut it off!'

(whoosh)
(music cuts)
'And then come down on rockets.'
(engines blast)
'Once we turn those rocket motors on-'
'if we dont do something, we're just going to smack right back into the parachute!'

(engines blast)
(music- big pounding drums)
'So the first thing we do is make this really radical 'divert maneuver''
'We fly off to the side.'
Adam Steltzner: 'Diverting away from the parachute, killing our horizontal velocity and our vertical velocity'
'getting the rover moving straight up and down, so it can look at the surface with its radar-'
'and see where we're gonna land.'
'And we head straight down'
'to the bottom of a crater'
'right beside a six kilometer-high mountain!'
(music- grand)
Anita Sengupta: 'We can't get those rocket engines too close to the ground.'
'Because if we were to descent propulsively all the way to the ground-
'we would essentially create this massive dust cloud. That dust cloud could then land on the rover-'
'It could damage mechanisms and it could damage instruments.'
'So the way we solve that problem, is by using the skycrane maneuver.'
Adam Steltzner: '20 meters above the surface, we have to lower the rover below us-'
'on a tether that's 21 feet long.'
'And then deposit it, on its wheels, on the surface.'
(music- intense and climactic)
Miguel San Martin: 'As the rover touches down and is now on the ground,'
'the descent stage- it's on a collision course with the rover!'
'We must cut the bridal immediately and fly the descent stage to a safe distance from the rover.'

(music crescendos and ends)
(thunderous rockets echo)

(music-final orchestra hit over dark drone)
(wind in background)
(music- dark drone continues with faint ticking sound)

title: Seven Minutes of Terror: The Challenges of Getting to Mars

comments.text: They should have called this rover "Complexity" ;)﻿
comments.author: Soft Kitty

comments.text:
The Mars rover, Curiosity, made headlines in the last few days after 
detecting nitrogen on the surface of Mars. But what did it take to get 
Curiosity safely to Mars? Siemens PLM software was used to enable component 
testing and mission simulation in a virtual environment. Watch the video to 
find out more: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ki_Af_o9Q9s﻿

within reduced offtime hours, precluding available time for schooling of 
any kind), I'd take online classes. To all the EDL (and all the other)

on backups. If you don't like this video, check your pulse.﻿

comments.text: Why can't Hubble take high def pictures of mars surface? ﻿
comments.author: rota cetle

comments.text:

Many Thanks
comments.author: rota cetle

comments.text:
Hubble has taken some great pictures of Mars over the years (
http://hubblesite.org/newscenter/archive/releases/solar-system/mars/) but 
it is only capable of seeing large scale global changes - features hundreds 
of km large.  To get images of the surface down to resolutions in the tens 
of metres less, you need a flyby or orbiter mission (like the Mars 
Reconnaissance Orbiter) taking the snapshots.

I'm not even sure it's technically possible to build a mirror large enough 
for an Earth orbiting telescope capable of seeing something the size of a 
house on Mars.
comments.author: Nicholas Hylton

Two years later, and Curiosity's landing it's still a mind-boggling piece 
of engineering.  And if any of you haven't hear about the book, The Martian 
(http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/18007564-the-martian), read it. It's a 
brilliant work of science fiction with an emphasis on the science. Great 
series of engineering problem-solving puzzles that high school physics and 
biology students should have to solve. Wonderful way to integrate language 
arts and science and engineering.﻿

comments.text:
I'll bet engineers in the 70's could have accomplished landing something on 
mars without 3 crazy systems (ultra high strength parachute, self driving 
rocket section and skycrane). I wonder how theyd do it without computers 
and advances in materials science though.﻿
comments.author: John Dobak

comments.text:
Wrong, John.  They had plenty of "crazy systems" in the 70s for the Space 
Program too.  They're absolutely necessary.    The difference between then 
and now is that space probes and spacecraft had way less computing power, 
so they have to engineer around those constraints and can only give those 
old spacecraft much simpler, shorter sets of commands.

Traveling through space and landing on other worlds isn't like dusting 
crops.  You can't just muddle your way through.

comments.text:
Not like this, they couldn't.
Curiosity is BIG. like... REALLY big.
That's a big part of it.
Also, they wanted a TIGHT landing zone. All previous landers have had 
landing zones of a few kilometers. Weve been checking out planes and boring 
shit like that.
Now curiosity, my babe, she wants to dare mighty things.Her LZ was WAY 
smaller.. weight was WAY more (so airbags are a no go)

I don't remember the show that talked about the Curiosity rover, but that 
parachute failed in the wind tunnel a LOT. Also, the cables always got 
tangled up testing it on Earth. Mars' gravity effects the cables enough 
that they only lowered properly on Mars. It must have been horrifying to 
know that waiting for it to land.

comments.text:
1:40 - An interesting fact about this part is that all that heat is not 
caused by air friction, as most people think. It's caused by air 
compression: air gets so much compressed in the front of the spacecraft 
that it heats up to those insane temperatures.

They're the blonds I know will hurt me, but I've pursued them just the same.
